answers.author: Cory Fleming
answers.text:
One of the reasons I'm a big proponent of CRM (constituent relationship management) systems is that the knowledgebase component of these systems allows local governments to capture the processes and procedures of how their service departments get things done.  And in capturing that information, local governments can also review those processes and procedures to determine if there's overlap, duplication of effort, bottlenecks, or new ways to streamline things.

answers.author: Candace Talmadge
answers.text:
Cory, you make a great point about how to use the information a CRM system can yield. CRM can also be used to manage key relationships as well, such as those with elected officials, regulators, or other government agencies. It's a great enabler of collaboration. Do you know of any local governments doing a good job of using CRM to capture and analyze their processes? I would be interested  in interviewing those involved with the policies and technology. I'm looking for case studies of technology enabled knowledge transfer. Thanks.

author: Candace Talmadge
text: I am helping to write an article for Public Management on the topic of how technology can enable knowledge transfer between the generation of leaders and managers who are retiring and the generation of leaders and managers who follow them. Does anyonne familiar with public sector technology issues have any thoughts on this topic, or know any examples of counties or cities using technology in this manner? I hope to do phone interviews during October. Thanks.
title: Knowledge transfer
